review.title: A Framework for Optimizing Paper Matching
review.abstract: At the heart of many scientific conferences is the problem of matching submitted papers to suitable reviewers. Arriving at a good assignment is a major and important challenge for any conference organizer. In this paper we propose a framework to optimize paper-to-reviewer assignments. Our framework uses suitability scores to measure pairwise affinity between papers and reviewers. We show how learning can be used to infer suitability scores from a small set of provided scores, thereby reducing the burden on reviewers and organizers. We frame the assignment problem as an integer program and propose several variations for the paper-to-reviewer matching domain. We also explore how learning and matching interact. Experiments on two conference data sets examine the performance of several learning methods as well as the effectiveness of the matching formulations.

sections.heading: 3 Matching Framework and Instantiations
sections.text: First, we outline our basic problem definition, and then address some specific instances of the framework we have developed, including the use of different learning methods to predict unknown aptitudes, a set of objectives and limitations of the matching process that reflect different desiderata for the review process, and interactions between the two.

sections.heading: 3.1 Problem Definition
sections.text: Our approach to the matching problem is based on aptitude values that describe the relevance of a reviewer to a particular work. The matching process uses these values to assign a series of articles to users. For the reasons mentioned above, the aptitude values are not fully specified. As we do not want to restrict the matching process to known reviewer-paper pairs, these must be predicted in some way. We formalize the matching problem as follows: Let us refer to users or reviewers, p-P to articles or papers, and let us know that each user-item pair has a aptitude scale. The summary of all results can be regarded as an aptitude matrix S-RN-M. Only a subset of aptitude criteria is observed, namely those collected by reviewers.

sections.heading: 3.2 Learning Methods
sections.text: We have researched a number of learning methods for predicting the suitability of reviewers for essays. Here, we focus on three methods, each of which provides different information for predicting. (D) We use the contents of the submitted essays and archived essays for predicting, but do not use simple language models to represent the predictions of essays and reviewers. (D) Our language model (LM) is based on these, and predicts the suitability without the use of predetermined reviewer preferences; rather, it builds a model in word (feature) that links the distance in that space with suitability. sections.heading: 3.3 Matching Objectives
sections.text: We articulate several different criteria that can influence the definition of "good" matching, and explore various formulations of the optimization problem that can be used to adjust these criteria. We also discuss how these criteria can interact with our learning methods. Of course, one wants to assign the papers submitted to their most suitable critics; of course, this is almost never possible, since some reviewers will be suitable for many more papers than others. In general, limiting the paper load increases the likelihood that certain papers will be assigned to very unsuitable reviewers. This indicates that only assignments with a score srp above a minimum number of points are made. This ensures that each paper is checked by a minimally suitable reviewer, but that it may not be feasible.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Results
sections.text: We start by describing the data sets used in our experiments. The rest of the section is divided into three parts: the first looks at the score predictions with the different learning models; the second focuses on matching quality and examines the soft constraints on the number of papers summarized per reviewer. Finally, the third part evaluates a transformation of the matching target and shows how the use of a transformed learning target can increase the performance of the transformed matching problem.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have developed a framework for assigning paper to reviewers in the context of scientific conferences, in which we can determine high-quality matches using one of several learning methods. Interestingly, page information in the collaborative filtering area is often only perceived as useful in the cold-start state, where few or no values are available. The performance of both the LM and LR, which use verbatim characteristics of reviewers and submitted work, shows that this is not the case in our field. We also investigated the trade-off between the match of quality and the distribution of paper loads, thereby avoiding the need to manually set limits on the burden on the reviewer. Finally, we showed that with the realistic assumption that usefulness is not linear in terms of the suitability of the results, we can discover better matches by using the same nonlinear transformation in the learning activity.
